rubric:
Rubric for Laughter essay:

"6": "The writing is exceptionally clear, focused, and interesting. It holds the reader's attention throughout. Main ideas stand out and are developed by strong support and rich details suitable to audience and purpose. The writing is characterized by: clarity, focus, and control; main idea(s) that stand out; supporting, relevant, carefully selected details; when appropriate, use of resources provides strong, accurate, credible support; a thorough, balanced, in-depth explanation / exploration of the topic; the writing makes connections and shares insights; content and selected details that are well-suited to audience and purpose. The organization enhances the central idea(s) and its development. The order and structure are compelling and move the reader through the text easily. The writing is characterized by: effective, perhaps creative, sequencing and paragraph breaks; the organizational structure fits the topic, and the writing is easy to follow; a strong, inviting beginning that draws the reader in and a strong, satisfying sense of resolution or closure; smooth, effective transitions among all elements (sentences, paragraphs, ideas); details that fit where placed. The writer has chosen a voice appropriate for the topic, purpose, and audience. The writer demonstrates deep commitment to the topic, and there is an exceptional sense of "writing to be read." The writing is expressive, engaging, or sincere. The writing is characterized by: an effective level of closeness to or distance from the audience (e.g., a narrative should have a strong personal voice, while an expository piece may require extensive use of outside resources and a more academic voice; nevertheless, both should be engaging, lively, or interesting. Technical writing may require greater distance.); an exceptionally strong sense of audience; the writer seems to be aware of the reader and of how to communicate the message most effectively. The reader may discern the writer behind the words and feel a sense of interaction; a sense that the topic has come to life; when appropriate, the writing may show originality, liveliness, honesty, conviction, excitement, humor, or suspense.",
"5": "The writing is clear, focused and interesting. It holds the reader's attention. Main ideas stand out and are developed by supporting details suitable to audience and purpose. The writing is characterized by: clarity, focus, and control; main idea(s) that stand out; supporting, relevant, carefully selected details; when appropriate, use of resources provides strong, accurate, credible support; a thorough, balanced explanation / exploration of the topic; the writing makes connections and shares insights; content and selected details that are well-suited to audience and purpose. The organization enhances the central idea(s) and its development. The order and structure are strong and move the reader through the text. The writing is characterized by: effective sequencing and paragraph breaks; the organizational structure fits the topic, and the writing is easy to follow; an inviting beginning that draws the reader in and a satisfying sense of resolution or closure; smooth, effective transitions among all elements (sentences, paragraphs, ideas); details that fit where placed. The writer has chosen a voice appropriate for the topic, purpose, and audience. The writer demonstrates commitment to the topic, and there is a sense of "writing to be read." The writing is expressive, engaging, or sincere. The writing is characterized by: an appropriate level of closeness to or distance from the audience (e.g., a narrative should have a strong personal voice, while an expository piece may require extensive use of outside resources and a more academic voice; nevertheless, both should be engaging, lively, or interesting. Technical writing may require greater distance.); a strong sense of audience; the writer seems to be aware of the reader and of how to communicate the message most effectively. The reader may discern the writer behind the words and feel a sense of interaction; a sense that the topic has come to life; when appropriate, the writing may show originality, liveliness, honesty, conviction, excitement, humor, or suspense.",
"4": "The writing is clear and focused. The reader can easily understand the main ideas. Support is present, although it may be limited or rather general. The writing is characterized by: an easily identifiable purpose; clear main idea(s); supporting details that are relevant, but may be overly general or limited in places; when appropriate, resources are used to provide accurate support; a topic that is explored / explained, although developmental details may occasionally be out of balance with the main idea(s); some connections and insights may be present; content and selected details that are relevant, but perhaps not consistently well-chosen for audience and purpose. Organization is clear and coherent. Order and structure are present, but may seem formulaic. The writing is characterized by: clear sequencing and paragraph breaks; an organization that may be predictable; a recognizable, developed beginning that may not be particularly inviting; a developed conclusion that may lack subtlety; a body that is easy to follow with details that fit where placed; transitions that may be stilted or formulaic; organization which helps the reader, despite some weaknesses. A voice is present. The writer seems committed to the topic, and there may be a sense of "writing to be read." In places, the writing is expressive, engaging, or sincere. The writing is characterized by: a suitable level of closeness to or distance from the audience; a sense of audience; the writer seems to be aware of the reader but has not consistently employed an appropriate voice. The reader may glimpse the writer behind the words and feel a sense of interaction in places; liveliness, sincerity, or humor when appropriate; however, at times the writing may be either inappropriately casual or personal, or inappropriately formal and stiff.",
"3": "The reader can understand the main ideas, although they may be overly broad or simplistic, and the results may not be effective. Supporting detail is often limited, insubstantial, overly general, or occasionally slightly off-topic. The writing is characterized by: an easily identifiable purpose and main idea(s); predictable or overly-obvious main ideas; or points that echo observations heard elsewhere; or a close retelling of another work; support that is attempted, but developmental details are often limited, uneven, somewhat off-topic, predictable, or too general (e.g., a list of underdeveloped points); details that may not be well-grounded in credible resources; they may be based on clichés, stereotypes or questionable sources of information; difficulties when moving from general observations to specifics. An attempt has been made to organize the writing; however, the overall structure is inconsistent or skeletal. The writing is characterized by: attempts at sequencing and paragraph breaks, but the order or the relationship among ideas may occasionally be unclear; a beginning and an ending which, although present, are either undeveloped or too obvious (e.g., "My topic is..."; "These are all the reasons that..."); transitions that sometimes work. The same few transitional devices (e.g., coordinating conjunctions, numbering, etc.) may be overused; a structure that is skeletal or too rigid; placement of details that may not always be effective; organization which lapses in some places, but helps the reader in others. The writer's commitment to the topic seems inconsistent. A sense of the writer may emerge at times; however, the voice is either inappropriately personal or inappropriately impersonal. The writing is characterized by: a limited sense of audience; the writer's awareness of the reader is unclear; an occasional sense of the writer behind the words; however, the voice may shift or disappear a line or two later and the writing become somewhat mechanical; a limited ability to shift to a more objective voice when necessary; text that is too short to demonstrate a consistent and appropriate voice.",
"2": "Main ideas and purpose are somewhat unclear or development is attempted but minimal. The writing is characterized by: a purpose and main idea(s) that may require extensive inferences by the reader; minimal development; insufficient details; irrelevant details that clutter the text; extensive repetition of detail. The writing lacks a clear organizational structure. An occasional organizational device is discernible; however, the writing is either difficult to follow and the reader has to reread substantial portions, or the piece is simply too short to demonstrate organizational skills. The writing is characterized by: some attempts at sequencing, but the order or the relationship among ideas is frequently unclear; a lack of paragraph breaks; a missing or extremely undeveloped beginning, body, and/or ending; a lack of transitions, or when present, ineffective or overused; a lack of an effective organizational structure; details that seem to be randomly placed, leaving the reader frequently confused. The writing provides little sense of involvement or commitment. There is no evidence that the writer has chosen a suitable voice. The writing is characterized by: little engagement of the writer; the writing tends to be largely flat, lifeless, stiff, or mechanical; a voice that is likely to be overly informal and personal; a lack of audience awareness; there is little sense of "writing to be read"; little or no hint of the writer behind the words. There is rarely a sense of interaction between reader and writer.",
"1": "The writing lacks a central idea or purpose. The writing is characterized by: ideas that are extremely limited or simply unclear; attempts at development that are minimal or nonexistent; the paper is too short to demonstrate the development of an idea. The writing lacks coherence; organization seems haphazard and disjointed. Even after rereading, the reader remains confused. The writing is characterized by: a lack of effective sequencing and paragraph breaks; a failure to provide an identifiable beginning, body and/or ending; a lack of transitions; pacing that is consistently awkward; the reader feels either mired down in trivia or rushed along too rapidly; a lack of organization which ultimately obscures or distorts the main point. The writing seems to lack a sense of involvement or commitment. The writing is characterized by: no engagement of the writer; the writing is flat and lifeless; a lack of audience awareness; there is no sense of "writing to be read"; no hint of the writer behind the words. There is no sense of interaction between writer and reader; the writing does not involve or engage the reader."
prompt:
We all understand the benefits of laughter. For example, someone once said, "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people." Many other people believe that laughter is an important part of any relationship. Tell a true story in which laughter was one element or part.

Given the prompt, write a bad essay that has many spelling mistakes, is completely off-topic and disorganized, have English and punctuation errors, has the style of a first or second grader's writing, and is overall poor.
essay:
Once upon a time, my frend and I went to the zoo. We saw lots of aminals like monkeys and tigers. But then I fll down and my frend laughed at me. It was not nice! But then I got up and we saw more anmials. I like giraffe best. They have long nek. My frend laffed again when I try to touch the giraffe. It was so funny.

After we go home, my frend and I played outside. We had lot of fun in the sun. I had a ball and we kicked it around. My frend kicked the ball to me and I tripped over it. My frend laughed so much that he started to cry. It was silly!

Then we go back inside and eat lunch. My mom made us grilled cheese sandwhiches. I ate mine so fast that I chocked on it. My frend laffed so hard that milk came out his nose. It was gross but also funny. 

In the end, laffter is important. It helps us bond and have fun. Even though my frend laffed at me a lot, I know he is just joking. We have fun together und play all the time. Laughter is good for our frendship. The end!

rubric:
Rubric for Resilience Essays:

"3": "Tells a story with ideas that are clearly focused on the topic and are thoroughly developed with specific, relevant details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are clear and logically sequenced. Command of language, including effective and compelling word choice and varied sentence structure, clearly supports the writer's purpose and audience. Consistent, appropriate use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
"2": "Tells a story with ideas that are somewhat focused on the topic and are developed with a mix of specific and/or general details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are logically sequenced. Adequate command of language, including effective word choice and clear sentences, supports the writer's purpose and audience. Adequate use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
"1": "Tells a story with ideas that are minimally focused on the topic and developed with limited and/or general details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are weak. Limited use of language, including lack of variety in word choice and sentences, may hinder support for the writer's purpose and audience. Limited use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
"0": "Ideas are not focused on the task and/or are undeveloped. No organization evident. Ineffective use of language for the writer's purpose and audience. Ineffective use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation."
prompt:
Resilience is the ability to bounce back from adversity, challenges, or setbacks. It involves staying strong, flexible, and optimistic even in difficult times. A resilient person is not easily discouraged and can find ways to move forward despite obstacles. Write a story about a time when you or someone you know demonstrated resilience in the face of a challenge.

Given the prompt, write an excellent essay that has no spelling or grammar mistakes, is very focused and organized very well, has advanced but appropriate vocabulary choice, and has the style of a tenth grader's writing.
essay:
Resilience is a trait that we often don't truly appreciate until we are faced with a challenge that tests our strength and determination. When my best friend Sarah was diagnosed with a serious illness last year, I saw firsthand just how resilient she truly was.

Sarah had always been the type of person who faced challenges head-on, with a positive attitude and a determination to overcome whatever obstacles stood in her way. So when she received the devastating news that she had cancer, I knew that she would approach this adversity with the same resilience and courage that she approached everything else in her life.

Despite the daunting road that lay ahead of her, Sarah never wavered in her determination to beat the illness. She underwent grueling treatments with grace and strength, never once complaining or feeling sorry for herself. Even on her worst days, when the pain was unbearable and the future seemed uncertain, she remained optimistic and focused on the goal of getting better.

As Sarah's friend, I watched in awe as she faced each setback with a resilience that I had never seen before. She refused to let the illness define her or dictate her future. Instead, she found ways to stay strong, flexible, and hopeful, even when the odds seemed stacked against her.

Through it all, Sarah never lost her sense of humor or her ability to find joy in the simple things in life. She drew strength from the love and support of her friends and family, and she never lost sight of the light at the end of the tunnel. Despite the challenges she faced, Sarah continued to move forward with grace and dignity, inspiring everyone around her with her unwavering resilience.

In the end, Sarah's resilience paid off. After months of treatment and countless setbacks, she emerged victorious, cancer-free and stronger than ever. Her journey was not an easy one, but it was a testament to the power of resilience in the face of adversity.

Seeing Sarah's journey taught me the true meaning of resilience. It is not about avoiding challenges or setbacks, but about facing them head-on with strength, determination, and a positive attitude. Sarah's story is a reminder that no matter how difficult the road may be, resilience can help us overcome even the toughest of obstacles and emerge stronger on the other side.

prompt:
Resilience is the ability to bounce back from adversity, challenges, or setbacks. It involves staying strong, flexible, and optimistic even in difficult times. A resilient person is not easily discouraged and can find ways to move forward despite obstacles. Write a story about a time when you or someone you know demonstrated resilience in the face of a challenge.

Given the prompt, write an average essay that has inconsistent but minimal spelling and grammar errors, but it lack coherent structure and organization, is minimally focused, and has the style of a fourth or fifth grader's writing, .
essay:
One time my friend Jane showed a lot of resilence. We were on the playground and she tripped and fell and scraped her knee really bad. She was crying and hurt but she didnt give up. She got up and wiped her tears and said she would be okay. She didnt let the pain stop her from having fun. She kept playing with us and didnt let the accident ruin her day. I was really proud of her for being so strong.

Resilence is important because it helps us keep going even when things get tough. Like when my dog ran away and I was sad, but I didnt give up hope. I kept looking for him and eventually found him. It taught me that even when bad things happen, we can still find a way to be happy again.

In conclusion, being resilent is a good trait to have. It helps us stay strong in the face of challenges and setbacks. I hope we can all be like my friend Jane and never give up no matter what happens.

Write a story about a time when you or someone you know demonstrated resilience in the face of a challenge.

Given the prompt, write a bad essay that has many spelling mistakes, is completely off-topic and disorganized, have English and punctuation errors, has the style of a first or second grader's writing, and is overall poor.
essay:
Once up on a time, I had a frend named Bob. He was so resilent when he fell off his bike and hurt his arm. He cried a lot, but then he decided to be strond. He said, "i am going to be okay no matter what!" He did not give up, even tho it hurt a lot.

Then, Bob went to the doktor and they gave him a cast for his arm. He did not let that stop him from playing with his friends. He said, "I can still use my other arm and leg to play games!" He was so happy and positiv even tho he had a boo boo on his arm.

Bob showed so much resilents that day. He did not let a little injuri get him down. He kept being happy, strond, and positiv no matter what. I am so proud of him for being so resilent in the face of a challange. He is the best frend ever!

"1": "Tells a story with ideas that are minimally focused on the topic and developed with limited and/or general details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are weak. Limited use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",

prompt:
Write about patience. Being patient means that you are understanding and tolerant. A patient person experience difficulties without complaining. Do only one of the following: write a story about a time when you were patient OR write a story about a time when someone you know was patient OR write a story in your own way about patience.

Given the prompt, write an excellent essay that has no spelling or grammar mistakes, is very focused and organized very well, has advanced but appropriate vocabulary choice, and has the style of a tenth grader's writing.
essay:
Patience is a virtue that not everyone possesses. It requires a great deal of understanding and tolerance to be patient in difficult situations. It is the ability to endure hardships without complaint and to remain calm in the face of adversity. And while it may not always be easy to be patient, the rewards of practicing this virtue are immense.

I remember a time when my best friend Sarah demonstrated incredible patience in a challenging situation. We were on a road trip to visit a friend in another state, and we found ourselves stuck in traffic for hours due to a major accident up ahead. As the minutes turned into hours and the line of cars seemed never-ending, I could feel my frustration building. But Sarah remained calm and collected, choosing to focus on the positives rather than the negatives.

Despite the uncomfortable heat and the loud honking of nearby cars, Sarah started playing some music on the radio and cracking jokes to lighten the mood. She even pulled out some snacks from our cooler and started sharing them with me, making the whole situation more bearable. Her ability to stay composed and optimistic in the face of such a frustrating ordeal was truly inspiring.

I couldn't help but admire Sarah's patience and grace under pressure. While I was ready to explode with anger and impatience, she showed me that it was possible to remain calm and positive even in the most stressful of situations. Her ability to see the bigger picture and not let small inconveniences ruin her mood was a valuable lesson for me.

In conclusion, patience is a valuable trait that not everyone possesses. It requires understanding, tolerance, and the ability to endure hardships without complaint. My friend Sarah's demonstration of patience during our road trip taught me the importance of remaining calm and positive in challenging situations. It is a virtue that I continue to strive for, knowing that the rewards of practicing patience are truly worth it in the end.

prompt:
Write about patience. Being patient means that you are understanding and tolerant. A patient person experience difficulties without complaining. Do only one of the following: write a story about a time when you were patient OR write a story about a time when someone you know was patient OR write a story in your own way about patience.

Given the prompt, write an average essay that has inconsistent but minimal spelling and grammar errors, but it lack coherent structure and organization, is minimally focused, and has the style of a fourth or fifth grader's writing, .
essay:
One time, I had to wait a long time for my mom to finish her important meeting. I was so bored and starting to get hungry. But I knew my mom had to work. So, I decided to be patient and wait quietly in the waiting room.

I played with some toys I found in the room. I built a tower out of blocks and pretended it was a castle. I also colored a picture of a dinosaur that was hanging on the wall. It was fun for a little bit, but then I got restless again.

I walked around the room, looking out the big windows. I saw cars driving by and people walking on the street. I wished I could go outside and play. But I knew I had to wait for my mom.

I decided to sit down and read a book I brought with me. It was a story about a brave knight who saved the princess from an evil dragon. I got lost in the story and forgot about how long I had been waiting.

Finally, my mom came out of the meeting. She thanked me for being patient and told me she was proud of me. I smiled and hugged her, happy that I could make her proud.

Being patient was hard, but I knew it was the right thing to do. I learned that sometimes, you have to wait for things to happen. And being patient can make you feel good inside.

essay: One day me and my friend Sarah was waiting in line for ice cream. We had to wait for a long time cause there was only one person serving. Sarah was getting really mad and started to cry. I said to her "Be patiens, it will be our turn soon." But she didn't listen and kept whining. Finally we got to the front of the line and she ordered a big sundae with extra whip cream. I just got a cone cause I didn't want to wait any longer. Sarah was still upset and didn't even enjoy her ice cream. I learned that being patient is important so you don't ruin your fun.

The writer has chosen a voice appropriate for the topic, purpose, and audience. The writer demonstrates commitment to the topic, and there is a sense of "writing to be read." The writing is expressive, engaging, or sincere. The writing is characterized by: an appropriate level of closeness to or distance from the audience (e.g., a narrative should have a strong personal voice, while an expository piece may require extensive use of outside resources and a more academic voice; nevertheless, both should be engaging, lively, or interesting. Technical writing may require greater distance.); a strong sense of audience; the writer seems to be aware of the reader and of how to communicate the message most effectively. The reader may discern the writer behind the words and feel a sense of interaction; a sense that the topic has come to life; when appropriate, the writing may show originality, liveliness, honesty, conviction, excitement, humor, or suspense.",
"4": "The writing is clear and focused. The reader can easily understand the main ideas. Support is present, although it may be limited or rather general. The writing is characterized by: an easily identifiable purpose; clear main idea(s); supporting details that are relevant, but may be overly general or limited in places; when appropriate, resources are used to provide accurate support; a topic that is explored / explained, although developmental details may occasionally be out of balance with the main idea(s); some connections and insights may be present; content and selected details that are relevant, but perhaps not consistently well-chosen for audience and purpose. Organization is clear and coherent. Order and structure are present, but may seem formulaic. The writing is characterized by: clear sequencing and paragraph breaks; an organization that may be predictable; a recognizable, developed beginning that may not be particularly inviting; a developed conclusion that may lack subtlety; a body that is easy to follow with details that fit where placed; transitions that may be stilted or formulaic; organization which helps the reader, despite some weaknesses. A voice is present. The writer seems committed to the topic, and there may be a sense of "writing to be read." In places, the writing is expressive, engaging, or sincere. The writing is characterized by: a suitable level of closeness to or distance from the audience; a sense of audience; the writer seems to be aware of the reader but has not consistently employed an appropriate voice. The reader may glimpse the writer behind the words and feel a sense of interaction in places; liveliness, sincerity, or humor when appropriate; however, at times the writing may be either inappropriately casual or personal, or inappropriately formal and stiff.",
"3": "The reader can understand the main ideas, although they may be overly broad or simplistic, and the results may not be effective. Supporting detail is often limited, insubstantial, overly general, or occasionally slightly off-topic. The writing is characterized by: an easily identifiable purpose and main idea(s); predictable or overly-obvious main ideas; or points that echo observations heard elsewhere; or a close retelling of another work; support that is attempted, but developmental details are often limited, uneven, somewhat off-topic, predictable, or too general (e.g., a list of underdeveloped points); details that may not be well-grounded in credible resources; they may be based on clichés, stereotypes or questionable sources of information; difficulties when moving from general observations to specifics. An attempt has been made to organize the writing; however, the overall structure is inconsistent or skeletal. The writing is characterized by: attempts at sequencing and paragraph breaks, but the order or the relationship among ideas may occasionally be unclear; a beginning and an ending which, although present, are either undeveloped or too obvious (e.g., "My topic is..."; "These are all the reasons that..."); transitions that sometimes work. The same few transitional devices (e.g., coordinating conjunctions, numbering, etc.) may be overused; a structure that is skeletal or too rigid; placement of details that may not always be effective; organization which lapses in some places, but helps the reader in others. The writer's commitment to the topic seems inconsistent. A sense of the writer may emerge at times; however, the voice is either inappropriately personal or inappropriately impersonal. The writing is characterized by: a limited sense of audience; the writer's awareness of the reader is unclear; an occasional sense of the writer behind the words; however, the voice may shift or disappear a line or two later and the writing become somewhat mechanical; a limited ability to shift to a more objective voice when necessary; text that is too short to demonstrate a consistent and appropriate voice.",
"2": "Main ideas and purpose are somewhat unclear or development is attempted but minimal. The writing is characterized by: a purpose and main idea(s) that may require extensive inferences by the reader; minimal development; insufficient details; irrelevant details that clutter the text; extensive repetition of detail. The writing lacks a clear organizational structure. An occasional organizational device is discernible; however, the writing is either difficult to follow and the reader has to reread substantial portions, or the piece is simply too short to demonstrate organizational skills. The writing is characterized by: some attempts at sequencing, but the order or the relationship among ideas is frequently unclear; a lack of paragraph breaks; a missing or extremely undeveloped beginning, body, and/or ending; a lack of transitions, or when present, ineffective or overused; a lack of an effective organizational structure; details that seem to be randomly placed, leaving the reader frequently confused. The writing provides little sense of involvement or commitment. There is no evidence that the writer has chosen a suitable voice. The writing is characterized by: little engagement of the writer; the writing tends to be largely flat, lifeless, stiff, or mechanical; a voice that is likely to be overly informal and personal; a lack of audience awareness; there is little sense of "writing to be read"; little or no hint of the writer behind the words. There is rarely a sense of interaction between reader and writer.",
"1": "The writing lacks a central idea or purpose. The writing is characterized by: ideas that are extremely limited or simply unclear; attempts at development that are minimal or nonexistent; the paper is too short to demonstrate the development of an idea. The writing lacks coherence; organization seems haphazard and disjointed. Even after rereading, the reader remains confused. The writing is characterized by: a lack of effective sequencing and paragraph breaks; a failure to provide an identifiable beginning, body and/or ending; a lack of transitions; pacing that is consistently awkward; the reader feels either mired down in trivia or rushed along too rapidly; a lack of organization which ultimately obscures or distorts the main point. The writing seems to lack a sense of involvement or commitment. The writing is characterized by: no engagement of the writer; the writing is flat and lifeless; a lack of audience awareness; there is no sense of "writing to be read"; no hint of the writer behind the words. There is no sense of interaction between writer and reader; the writing does not involve or engage the reader."
prompt:
We all understand the benefits of laughter. For example, someone once said, "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people." Many other people believe that laughter is an important part of any relationship. Tell a true story in which laughter was one element or part.

Given the prompt, write an excellent essay that has no spelling or grammar mistakes, is very focused and organized very well, has advanced but appropriate vocabulary choice, and has the style of a tenth grader's writing.
essay:
Laughter has always been an essential element in my relationship with my best friend, Maya. Despite living miles apart, our bond has only grown stronger over the years, thanks in part to our shared sense of humor.

One summer, Maya and I decided to take a road trip to visit some college campuses. As we drove through the scenic countryside, we found ourselves lost in conversation, sharing funny anecdotes and cracking jokes along the way. Our laughter filled the car, making the long journey feel short and enjoyable.

One evening, as we were driving to our next destination, Maya suddenly pointed out a sign for a nearby amusement park. Without hesitation, we decided to make a spontaneous detour and spend the rest of the day riding roller coasters and indulging in sugary treats.

As we waited in line for our first ride, Maya couldn't contain her excitement and started making funny faces at the people around us. I couldn't help but burst into laughter, causing a ripple effect among the other riders in line. Suddenly, we found ourselves surrounded by strangers, all sharing in our joy and laughter.

Throughout the day, Maya and I found ourselves in one hilarious situation after another – from getting stuck on a malfunctioning ride to accidentally spilling ice cream on ourselves. But through it all, we laughed until our stomachs hurt, creating memories that would last a lifetime.

By the end of the day, as we drove back to our hotel, exhausted but elated, Maya turned to me and said, "I'm so grateful to have you as my best friend. Our laughter is the glue that holds us together, no matter how far apart we may be."

In that moment, I realized just how important laughter truly is in any relationship. It has the power to bridge the gap between two people, to create a sense of closeness and camaraderie that transcends physical distance. And in my friendship with Maya, laughter has been the thread that has woven our bond tighter than ever before.

As we continue to navigate life's ups and downs, I know that as long as we can still find reasons to laugh together, our friendship will remain unbreakable. For laughter truly is the shortest distance between two people – a bridge that connects hearts, minds, and souls in a way that nothing else can. And for that, I am forever grateful.

rubric:

prompt:
We all understand the benefits of laughter. For example, someone once said, "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people." Many other people believe that laughter is an important part of any relationship. Tell a true story in which laughter was one element or part.

Given the prompt, write an average essay that has inconsistent but minimal spelling and grammar errors, but it lack coherent structure and organization, is minimally focused, and has the style of a fourth or fifth grader's writing, .
essay:
One time me and my best friend Lily were at recess and we were swinging on the swings. Lily was trying to swing really high and she ended up falling off her swing! I was really worried but she just started laughing and laughing. I couldn't help but giggle too and soon we were both rolling on the ground laughing so hard.

After that, we couldn't stop laughing every time we saw each other. We would just look at each other and burst out laughing, even if nothing was funny. It was like we had our own inside joke that only we understood.

One day, we were in class and our teacher was writing on the board. She accidentally spelled a word wrong and we both looked at each other and started cracking up. Our teacher didn't know what was so funny but we just couldn't stop laughing.

That laughter brought us closer together and made our friendship even stronger. We knew that no matter what happened, we could always count on each other to make us laugh. Laughter really is the best medicine, especially when you can share it with someone you care about.

prompt:
We all understand the benefits of laughter. For example, someone once said, "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people." Many other people believe that laughter is an important part of any relationship. Tell a true story in which laughter was one element or part.

Given the prompt, write a bad essay that has many spelling mistakes, is completely off-topic and disorganized, have English and punctuation errors, has the style of a first or second grader's writing, and is overall poor.
essay:
One time, me and my friend were playing at the park. We were having so much fun swinging on the swings and going down the slide. Then, my friend told a joke about a chicken crossing the road. I laughed so hard that milk came out of my nose!

It was so funny because the chicken was wearing sunglasses and a hat. We couldn't stop laughing for a long time. It felt good to laugh with my friend because it made me happy.

After we were done laughing, we played some more on the monkey bars and pretended to be superheroes. I was superman and my friend was batman. We saved the park from the evil monkeys who were trying to take over.

Even though we were just kids playing pretend, we had so much fun together. Laughter is important because it brings people together and makes everything better. I love laughing with my friend and I can't wait to do it again. Laughing is the best!

rubric:
Rubric for Resilience Essays:

"3": "Tells a story with ideas that are clearly focused on the topic and are thoroughly developed with specific, relevant details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are clear and logically sequenced. Command of language, including effective and compelling word choice and varied sentence structure, clearly supports the writer's purpose and audience. Consistent, appropriate use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
"2": "Tells a story with ideas that are somewhat focused on the topic and are developed with a mix of specific and/or general details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are logically sequenced. Adequate command of language, including effective word choice and clear sentences, supports the writer's purpose and audience. Adequate use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
"1": "Tells a story with ideas that are minimally focused on the topic and developed with limited and/or general details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are weak. Limited use of language, including lack of variety in word choice and sentences, may hinder support for the writer's purpose and audience. Limited use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
"0": "Ideas are not focused on the task and/or are undeveloped. No organization evident. Ineffective use of language for the writer's purpose and audience. Ineffective use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation."
prompt:
Resilience is the ability to bounce back from adversity, challenges, or setbacks. It involves staying strong, flexible, and optimistic even in difficult times. A resilient person is not easily discouraged and can find ways to move forward despite obstacles. Write a story about a time when you or someone you know demonstrated resilience in the face of a challenge.

Given the prompt, write an excellent essay that has no spelling or grammar mistakes, is very focused and organized very well, has advanced but appropriate vocabulary choice, and has the style of a tenth grader's writing.
essay:
Resilience is a quality that is not easily come by, but when demonstrated, it can be truly inspiring. I remember a time when my best friend, Sarah, showed incredible resilience in the face of a major challenge.

It was during our sophomore year of high school when Sarah's family faced financial difficulties. Her parents had lost their jobs due to the economic downturn, and they were struggling to make ends meet. As a result, Sarah had to take on more responsibilities at home, including getting a part-time job to help support her family.

Despite the stress and uncertainty that her family was facing, Sarah remained steadfast and focused. She never complained or let the situation bring her down. Instead, she took on her new responsibilities with determination and a positive attitude. She worked tirelessly at her job, balancing it with her schoolwork and extracurricular activities.

I remember one particularly difficult day when Sarah came to school looking visibly tired and worn out. She had worked a double shift the night before to cover for a sick coworker, and she was running on only a few hours of sleep. But instead of feeling sorry for herself, Sarah simply brushed off her exhaustion and got through the day with a smile on her face.

Through it all, Sarah never lost sight of her goals and dreams. She knew that her family's financial situation was only temporary, and she remained hopeful for the future. She stayed focused on her studies, continued to excel in her extracurricular activities, and never gave up on her dreams of going to college.

In the end, Sarah's resilience paid off. Her family eventually overcame their financial difficulties, and she was able to graduate high school with honors. She went on to attend her dream college on a scholarship, where she continued to excel academically and make a positive impact on those around her.

Sarah's story serves as a reminder that resilience is not just about bouncing back from adversity, but also about staying strong, flexible, and optimistic in the face of challenges. It is a quality that can help us navigate life's ups and downs with grace and determination. And it is a quality that Sarah demonstrated in spades, inspiring all those around her to never give up, no matter how tough the road ahead may seem.

rubric:
Rubric for Resilience Essays:

"3": "Tells a story with ideas that are clearly focused on the topic and are thoroughly developed with specific, relevant details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are clear and logically sequenced. Command of language, including effective and compelling word choice and varied sentence structure, clearly supports the writer's purpose and audience. Consistent, appropriate use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",

Limited use of language, including lack of variety in word choice and sentences, may hinder support for the writer's purpose and audience. Limited use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",

prompt:
Resilience is the ability to bounce back from adversity, challenges, or setbacks. It involves staying strong, flexible, and optimistic even in difficult times. A resilient person is not easily discouraged and can find ways to move forward despite obstacles. Write a story about a time when you or someone you know demonstrated resilience in the face of a challenge.

Given the prompt, write an average essay that has inconsistent but minimal spelling and grammar errors, but it lack coherent structure and organization, is minimally focused, and has the style of a fourth or fifth grader's writing, .
essay:
One time my friend David showed a lot of resilience when he didn't make the basketball team at school. He was really sad at first, but he didn't give up. He kept practicing every day after school and working on his skills.

Even though he wasn't on the team, he still went to every game and cheered on his friends. He didn't let not making the team get him down. Instead, he used it as motivation to work harder and try again next year.

I think David is really strong and brave for not giving up when things got tough. He could have easily just quit and been sad, but he didn't. He stayed positive and focused on getting better.

In the end, David's hard work paid off. The next year, he tried out for the team again and he made it! He was so happy and proud of himself. I was really happy for him too. It just shows that if you keep going and don't give up, you can do anything you set your mind to. David is a great example of resilience and I'm glad to have him as a friend.

prompt:
Resilience is the ability to bounce back from adversity, challenges, or setbacks. It involves staying strong, flexible, and optimistic even in difficult times. A resilient person is not easily discouraged and can find ways to move forward despite obstacles. Write a story about a time when you or someone you know demonstrated resilience in the face of a challenge.

Given the prompt, write a bad essay that has many spelling mistakes, is completely off-topic and disorganized, have English and punctuation errors, has the style of a first or second grader's writing, and is overall poor.
essay:
One time, there was a boy named Timmy who was very resilent. he was going throug a tuff time becasue his dog ran away. He looked everywhere for his dog but culdnt find him. He was so sad and cryed a lot. But then he decieded to be strong and kepe looking for him no matter what. He askd all his neighbors if they saw his dog and put up fliers all over town. He didnt give up hope even wen it seemed like his dog was gone forever. 

Finally, after many days of searching, Timmy found his dog hiding in the bushs. He was so happy and felt like he cud do anything now. He leraned that its important to never give up even wen things seem hard. Timmy was really proud of himself for being resilent and not quiting. He now knows that he can face any challenge that comes his way. 

In conclusion, being resilent is imporant becasue it helps you get throught tuff times and come out stronger on the other side. Timmy is a good exampel of someone who showed resilence wen his dog ran away. He is a true example of what it means to be strong, flexable, and optimistic in the face of a challnge.
